channel.title: NYT > Arts

item.title: Best Comedy of 2025
item.description: Late-night came roaring back to life, Roy Wood Jr. delivered a must-see special and Amy Poehler made a must-listen podcast.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: America Wants to Build Again. If You Squint, You’ll See Hopeful Signs.
item.description: Crumbling highways. A housing shortage. Broken infrastructure. America is stuck. But the pendulum may be ready to swing.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman

item.title: How Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Became a Gaming Tour de Force
item.description: Without a blockbuster budget or much experience, the creators of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 astounded the industry with an emotional narrative and old-school design.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Two Women Who Kept the Art World at Arm’s Length
item.description: Agnes Martin and Jay De Feo spent a lifetime searching for clarity of thought. Their works glow in these two shows.
item.dc:creator: Max Lakin

item.title: ‘Afternoons of Solitude’ Looks for Beauty in the Bloodshed of Bullfighting
item.description: Albert Serra’s documentary “Afternoons of Solitude” seeks something transcendent in a tradition that many people, in Spain and elsewhere, find barbaric.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Cinema brings you closer to life itself,” Albert Serra said.

item.title: In ‘Sunday Without Love,’ Ragnar Kjartansson Plays With Sentiment
item.description: Paradox is at the heart of a new video by the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson, “Sunday Without Love,” which has its romantic side and undercuts it, too.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: ‘Ella McCay’ Review: Right Girl, Wrong Time
item.description: James L. Brooks returns with a lieutenant governor comedy that might leave you more confused than amused.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Resurrection’ Review: Bi Gan’s Voyage Into Cinema
item.description: The Chinese director Bi Gan, who has become a lauded fixture on the festival circuit, conjures a boundary-pushing tale that evokes moviemaking itself.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Dust Bunny’ Review: A World of Wonders, Familiar and Foreign
item.description: The movie, starring Sophie Sloan and Mads Mikkelsen, is a blast of visual delights.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Dominates at the Game Awards
item.description: The role-playing game won nine prizes, including game of the year.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.category: Death Stranding 2: On the Beach (Video Game)

item.title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
item.description: A holiday album that cuts through seasonal glut, a late collaboration by Jim McNeely and Helmut Lachenmann’s string quartets are among the highlights.

item.title: 16 Best Theater Moments of 2025
item.description: Lea Michele’s star turn in “Chess.” Kara Young as an 8-year-old. A 12-minute monologue delivered from a cloud. These are our favorite scenes from this year.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes, Alexis Soloski and Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Ryan Coogler on ‘Sinners,’ Chadwick Boseman and Why He Declined to Join the Academy
item.description: The director on what he’s thinking of post-“Sinners,” how the loss of Chadwick Boseman affected him and why he turned down the invitation to join the academy.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Ariel Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coogler said he couldn’t engage with his work “as the kid whose dreams were to come to Hollywood and make movies. I have to engage with it as a professional shepherd of the story.”

item.title: Sundance 2026 Lineup Includes Charli XCX and Olivia Wilde
item.description: Olivia Wilde will also appear in two films, including one she directed, and the cast of “Little Miss Sunshine” will return for its 20th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Charli XCX in “The Moment,” directed by Aidan Zamiri.

item.title: D.L. Coburn, Playwright With a Solo Hit, ‘The Gin Game,’ Dies at 87
item.description: His two-character work won a Pulitzer Prize and had a long Broadway run, but he never replicated its success and struggled to get his later work staged.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy — husband and wife in real life — starred in the original Broadway production of “The Gin Game,” directed by Mike Nichols.

item.title: Smithsonian Returns Three Khmer Artifacts Thought Looted to Cambodia
item.description: Museum and Cambodian officials said they jointly investigated the provenance of the objects and found sufficient evidence to suggest they had been stolen.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg

item.title: The Artists Reviving the Legacy of Air Afrique
item.description: Plus: a new Manhattan bathhouse, textiles woven from pineapple leaves and more recommendations from T Magazine.

item.title: U.K. Police Seek Suspects in Theft of Over 600 Artifacts From Museum
item.description: The items were stolen in a “high-value burglary” from the Bristol Museum’s British Empire and Commonwealth collection, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Tess Felder and Alex Marshall

item.title: ‘Silent Night, Deadly Night’ Review: A Slasher Gets a Giddy Reboot
item.description: This delightfully trashy entry in the seasonal subgenre follows a killer Santa with a heart, and a case of blood lust.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘The King of Color’ Review: He’s Just Into Hue
item.description: In a new documentary, the creator of the Pantone system explains how he standardized colors across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Atropia’ Review: No Escape From Reality
item.description: Alia Shawkat and Callum Turner fake it so real in this Army simulation exercise in the California desert.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: Our Favorite Hidden Gem Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of the Book Review recommends unforgettable books that made our personal best-of-the-year lists.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff

item.title: Late Night Tries to Decipher Another Rambling Trump Speech
item.description: Among other things, President Trump claimed to be a big hit with Black voters. But Desi Lydic says her potato salad is getting better numbers.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Donald McIntyre, 91, Dies; Starred in New Vision of Wagner’s Operas
item.description: As Wotan in Patrice Chéreau’s neo-Marxist staging of the “Ring” cycle, he was part of a celebrated, polarizing moment in opera history.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Donald McIntyre as Wotan and Gwyneth Jones as Brünnhilde in Wagner’s “Die Walküre” at the Royal Opera in London in 1978. Two years before, Mr. McIntyre had starred as Wotan (alongside Ms. Jones) in a groundbreaking new production of Wagner’s “Ring” operas at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany.

item.title: The President of the Yaddo Artist Retreat Steps Down
item.description: After a quarter century, the Yaddo president Elaina Richardson will step down, having made her mark on the storied arts residency.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times
item.media:description: In her 25 years leading Yaddo, Elaina Richardson has increased the artist residency’s endowment more than fourfold.

item.title: Stephen Downing, Police Officer Who Wrote for TV, Dies at 87
item.description: While serving in the L.A.P.D., he began delivering scripts for series like “Dragnet” and “Adam-12.” After retiring, he was a showrunner for “MacGyver.”
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: ‘Rocky’ Statue to Move to Where It Started: Philadelphia’s Art Museum Steps
item.description: It’s a symbol of the city. But is it art?
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Sylvester Stallone with the Rocky statue outside the Philadelphia Art Museum in 2018.

item.title: A Stranger Found Ricki Lake’s Lost Family Photos After L.A. Wildfires
item.description: Patty Scanlon bought a box of snapshots for $20 at a flea market and was stunned to find family photos of Ms. Lake, whose house burned down in January.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Wendy Osefo Is Among the Latest ‘Real Housewives’ Stars in Legal Trouble
item.description: Osefo, of “The Real Housewives of Potomac,” faces several counts of fraud. She is the latest in a long line of “Housewives” personalities to face legal trouble.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Wendy Osefo of “The Real Housewives of Potomac” and her husband, Edward Osefo, were indicted on fraud charges in October.

item.title: Charity Raffle Offers a Chance at a Picasso for a $120 Ticket
item.description: A French charity is raffling Picasso’s 1941 portrait “Tête de femme,” valued at more than 1 million euros, for €100 a ticket to raise funds for Alzheimer’s research.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: History Colorado Center Rejects Painting, Citing Campaign Finance Law
item.description: A Colorado museum cited state law while rejecting an artwork with unflattering depictions of politicians. Free speech groups called the decision censorship.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: ‘Merv’ Review: Not Much to Gnaw On
item.description: Zooey Deschanel and Charlie Cox play a former couple who share a dog in this shaggy rom-com that fails its titular lead.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: Jennifer Shah, Former ‘Real Housewives’ Star, Is Released Early From Prison
item.description: The onetime cast member was sentenced to six and a half years in 2023 after pleading guilty to participating in a telemarketing scheme that defrauded thousands of victims.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City (TV Program)
item.media:description: Jennifer Shah leaving federal court in Manhattan in 2023.

item.title: Sophie Kinsella, ‘Confessions of a Shopaholic’ Author, Dies at 55
item.description: Writing under a pseudonym, Madeleine Wickham cultivated an international following for her series centered on a young woman addicted to shopping.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Sandra Mickiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British author Madeleine Wickham in 2024. Under the pen name Sophie Kinsella, she wrote nine “Shopaholic” novels, which sold tens of millions of copies and were translated into dozens of languages.

item.title: Rare 15th Century Jewish Prayer Book, Looted by the Nazis, to Be Sold
item.description: The illuminated manuscript, confiscated from the Rothschild banking dynasty during the Holocaust, is expected to draw at least $5 million.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal

item.title: Our Phones Are Making Us Lonely. There’s Drama in That.
item.description: Savvy theater makers are exploring the debasing effects of online culture on relationships.
item.dc:creator: Houman Barekat

item.title: Jessie Buckley is a Grieving Mother in Hamnet
item.description: Jessie Buckley, star of “Hamnet,” on the primal love — and grief — of motherhood.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Christina Djossa, Amy Pearl, Sara Curtis, Elisa Gutierrez, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez and Dan Powell
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Background: Brian Rea; Inset photo: Chris Pizzello/Invision, via Associated Press

item.title: The Best Genre Movies of 2025
item.description: We look at the finest in science fiction, horror, action and international films, all available to stream.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli, Erik Piepenburg, Robert Daniels and Devika Girish
item.media:description: Aaron Taylor-Johnson, top, and Alfie Williams in a scene from "28 Years Later.”

item.title: 15 Deep-Dive, Goodies-Filled Boxed Sets and Reissues From 2025
item.description: Some of the year’s most thrilling music was its oldest: Rock icons dug into their archives, underground ’90s rap and indie figures put out long-awaited vinyl and more.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles, Hank Shteamer, Ben Sisario and Lindsay Zoladz
item.category: Music From the Land of the Sky: The 1925 Asheville Sessions (Album)
Telepathic Fish: Trawling the Early 90s Ambient Underground (Album)

item.title: Why Return to ‘A Christmas Carol’? To Find Something New.
item.description: Popping up once a year, works like “A Christmas Carol,” “Amahl and the Night Visitors” and “It’s a Wonderful Life” help us gauge where we are in our lives.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Perelman, Ronald O, Performing Arts Center
It's a Wonderful Life: A Live Radio Play (Play)
item.media:credit: Rachel Papo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “A Christmas Carol” at Perelman Performing Arts Center in Manhattan.

item.title: “Pluribus” and “The Beast In Me” Put Women Writers Front and Center
item.description: “Pluribus,” “The Beast In Me” and “Die My Love” take viewers inside the minds and egos of their complex protagonists.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: ‘Allison After NXIVM’ Untangles a Cult Disciple’s Years of Delusional Thinking
item.description: The actress Allison Mack, who was sent to prison for crimes she committed as a member of NXIVM, tells her story for the first time in the new podcast.
item.dc:creator: Reggie Ugwu
item.media:description: Over seven episodes, Allison Mack discusses being introduced to NXIVM and falling under the thrall of the cult’s leader, Keith Raniere.

item.title: Late Night Doesn’t Want to Sweat at the Airport
item.description: Ronny Chieng dissed new fitness plans from the Trump administration for travelers in American airports: “We can’t even walk to the gate. They had to invent floors that walk for us.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Vistas Painted by Georgia O’Keeffe Protected by Conservation Plan
item.description: The plan will protect 6,000 acres of land in northern New Mexico, and the state is giving more than $900,000 toward the effort.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Jubilant Sykes, Celebrated Opera Singer, Is Stabbed to Death
item.description: After the police found the Grammy-nominated performer in his home with fatal wounds, his son was taken into custody, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jubilant Sykes performing as the Celebrant in “Mass,” by Leonard Bernstein, at Carnegie Hall in 2008.

item.title: Turner Prize Goes to Nnena Kalu, Sculpture Artist With a Learning Disability
item.description: Nnena Kalu, who uses cardboard and tape to create her work, received the prestigious art award.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Timbaland’s Latest Protégée Is an A.I. Pop Singer
item.description: The producer dreamed up TaTa Taktumi and brought her to life with help from the software Suno. She’s arriving at a fraught moment for artificial intelligence in music.
item.dc:creator: David Peisner
item.media:description: Timbaland calls TaTa Taktumi, the new pop star he is developing, a “hybrid” of work done by humans and A.I. (The person pictured here, who is indeed real, has played the role of TaTa.)

item.title: My 5 Favorite Film Scores of 2025
item.description: Nine Inch Nails’ music for “Tron: Ares,” Nala Sinephro’s compositions for “The Smashing Machine” and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails

item.title: Book Review: ‘Cape Fever,’ by Nadia Davids
item.description: In “Cape Fever,” a young maid finds herself dealing with ghosts from the past and a manipulative employer.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib

item.title: When the Phone Number in That TV Show Actually Connects Somewhere
item.description: Passing on the classic 555 number, “Stranger Things” is the latest show to offer Easter eggs for viewers who try to call a fictional character.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: DéLana R.A. Dameron, Writer of the Black South, Dies at 40
item.description: An award-winning poet and writer of fiction, she moonlighted as a competitive horsewoman and owned a horse farm outside Columbia, S.C.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Ranking New Holiday Specials From ‘Family Guy,’ ‘Fraggle Rock’ and More
item.description: Top picks for seasonal TV cheer include concerts from Nashville and the Tabernacle Choir, along with a new “Nutcracker” on PBS.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale

item.title: Raul Malo, Frontman of Latin-Tinged Country Band Mavericks, Dies at 60
item.description: As the group’s singer and principal songwriter, he brought a new sound that broadened the boundaries of country music in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.media:description: Raul Malo performing in 2022. Sticking to tradition and one genre, he said, “just wasn’t for me.”

item.title: These Looted Benin Bronzes Are Home. What Now?
item.description: Western museums are returning the Benin Bronzes to Nigeria, but a state-of-the-art museum to display them is still a long way off.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Museum of West African Art (Benin City, Nigeria)
item.media:credit: Stephen Tayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nkechi Adedeji, Olugbile Holloway and Tunji Busari examining a recently returned Benin Bronze at the National Museum in Lagos, Nigeria.

item.title: What Streaming TV Could Learn from ‘Mad Men’
item.description: The classic show arrived on HBO Max with an embarrassing remastering error. But the show’s creative mastery remains undeniable.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.media:description: Jon Hamm in “Mad Men,” now streaming on HBO Max.

item.title: How Art Is Driving Waymo’s Feel-Good Branding
item.description: A tech giant has teamed up with local artists, adding vibrant colors and quirky characters in an effort to humanize its futuristic ride.
item.dc:creator: Jori Finkel
item.media:credit: Jamie Lee Taete for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Waymo self-driving car in Los Angeles wrapped with art by Tommii Lim. His cartoon cat is a stand-in for the target Waymo customer, who enjoys kicking back and relinquishing control of the wheel.

item.title: Best Classical Performances of 2025
item.description: Thinking outside the canon, and finding the gritty and the beautiful, within it.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone and Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.media:description: Nadine Sierra in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “La Sonnambula,” directed by Rolando Villazón.

item.title: MoMA PS1 Will Be Free for Everyone, Not Just New Yorkers
item.description: Free admission begins in January, thanks to a donation. Officials expect visitation to climb as the Queens-based museum celebrates its 50th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Camilo Fuentealba for The New York Times
item.media:description: A $900,000 gift from Sonya Yu, a multidisciplinary creative entrepreneur and art collector, is making admissions free at MoMA PS1 for three years.

item.title: Top 10 Video Games of 2025
item.description: Autobiographical stories and mystery games resonated in a chaotic year.
item.dc:creator: Yussef Cole
item.category: The Seance of Blake Manor (Video Game)

item.title: My 5 Favorite Works of Art in Tokyo
item.description: Our critic Jason Farago shares what you shouldn’t miss in a bustling city that is best discovered at a leisurely pace.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago

item.title: ‘Alan’s Universe’ Shows What It Might Look Like to Win at YouTube
item.description: As Gen Alpha’s attention drifts from TV and movies, video creators like Alan Chikin Chow are eager to fill the void.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Philip Cheung
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
